title: Private markets alluring but caution needed
text:
She also notes an increase in market volatility. “Swings [in share prices] can be quite dramatic even to companies reporting a small shortfall in earnings."

Right mindset

Private markets can offer low correlations with other asset classes and better valuations than listed investments, she argues.

But investors need to have the right mindset for private market investing. “For clients who are patient and willing to tolerate less liquidity, private investing can make sense," says Crowther-Pal.

It could be beneficial to someone in their 40s with a self-managed superannuation fund, for example, she says.

Crowther-Pal defines a private market investment as “anything that isn’t publicly listed”. That can include private equity, venture capital, direct investing in debt and equity.

“There’s a depth to the private company universe,” she notes. “In terms of innovation, it’s quite rich.”

She’s not pursuing single companies but accessing the private sphere through a professional portfolio manager.

Advertisement

“We don’t look at individual companies as that would require targeted due diligence and would take a very long time. Instead we are working with professional money managers that source private equity and private debt investments,” she adds.

'Non-homogenous umbrella'

Private debt fund manager Bob Sahota, chief investment officer of Revolution Asset Management, calls the private sphere “a non-homogenous umbrella”.

Private debt fund manager Bob Sahota, chief investment officer of Revolution Asset Management. Jessica Hromas

In debt markets, for example, a private investment can cover corporate loans, infrastructure debt and special situation debt such as distressed debt.

“Lending to a fish and chip shop is private debt," says Sahota, former head of fixed income at Challenger.

He now runs a fund that invests in private debt, which launched in February 2018. The fund vehicle’s terms were “quite stringent” when it launched, he says, including a long lock-up period. Investors were unenthusiastic about investing in the fund at that time, he admits.

“Investors said ‘it sounds interesting but the structure isn’t good and we are not locking up our money’,” he says.

Advertisement

But as interest rates have come down, investor focus on returns has sharpened.

“There’s not much yield in the market,” Sahota says. “Now 6 per cent to 7 per cent is considered to be high yield. Everything with a plus in front of it looks quite good now.”

But there are risks to private market investing, including opaque valuations and illiquidity.

“From our perspective we don’t typically recommend private investments,” says Vincent O’Neill, director of private wealth at financial planning firm Stanford Brown.

“It has a role,” he adds, but “we are not adding private assets at the core".

Those of his clients who invest in private markets are usually leveraging off their own experience, he adds. Typically they have specialist knowledge.

“The challenge for some of these private investments is that they can look attractive but they are not always,” he explains. “We are not against it but it needs due diligence.”

Right diversification

Advertisement

Private investments can be difficult to enter due to minimum investment levels and there may not be the same level of disclosure as in publicly listed assets, he notes.

O'Neill cautions against heavily weighting portfolios towards the private sphere.

"Investors need the right diversification. These assets have a role to play but you don’t want to end up in concentrated positions," he says. “If private investments were 20 per cent to 30 per cent of a portfolio, we would be quite cautious."

O’Neill cites physical gold as an example of an asset that would be a “private investment you probably don’t want to own”, given the difficulty of storing gold.

"There are going to be risks and you have to understand the risks that you are taking," he adds.

"There is a risk to illiquid investments but it is balancing that risk and reward and mitigating risk by due diligence [that is key],” says Crowther-Pal.

Fees can be on the high side, she adds, But fees reflect high barriers to entry and the extensive filtering processes by portfolio managers, she adds. "These fund managers are distilling a very large universe through to a very small space.

"Investors have to ask if the fees are worth the alpha generated. It’s a space to watch from an investment perspective but, as with all investments, you need to be very sceptical.”
description: As valuations have risen in many publicly listed assets, the challenge of achieving an appropriate return has increased incrementally.
